BE11:08am

Let's cut to Morgan Stanley to tell us why we're here.

BE11:08am

Following a meeting between Ireland's Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson, both sides briefed that there is a "pathway to a deal" by the end of October. We think a deal can be negotiated, with the UK accepting a customs border in the Irish Sea and the EU allowing for a consent mechanism. While we think the chances of a deal being approved by the current parliament are limited, we would see a significantly reduced risk of a no-deal outcome should Prime Minister Johnson shift to a NI-only backstop

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Moving the customs border is key: It remains unclear what developments led to a constructive tone of the post-meeting briefings. We think a deal is negotiable if the UK agrees to a customs border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK - i.e. a complete NI-only backstop, with the EU potentially agreeing to a modified version of the consent process proposed by Prime Minister Johnson. Media reports suggest the EU is willing to countenance an exit mechanism for Northern Ireland with a "double majority" - approval from both the nationalist and the unionists - in the NI Assembly needed to leave the backstop. Elections before Brexit: We see only 30% chance of such a deal being approved in the current parliament, as we assume the DUP would oppose it, as well as a solid number of ERG/unionist Conservative MPs. We continue to see elections as the most plausible way to decide the way forward on Brexit and expect them to be held before Brexit. However, if a Johnson government were to switch to supporting a negotiable deal, then we would see a significantly reduced risk of a no-deal outcome after elections, since even a 'Leave' government would prefer an orderly exit to a no-deal outcome.

BE11:08am

Give us the % probabilities, MOST. You know you want to.

BE11:08am

Should the EU and the UK enter the 'negotiating tunnel' ahead of the European Council summit next week (17-18 October), we would increase our probability of a negotiated Brexit as the final outcome from 35% to 55%. We will be watching the outcome of the meeting between Barnier and the UK Brexit Secretary Barclay tomorrow, as it is likely to show whether there is any scope for a deal to be struck.

Bluesky21 Boris is going to throw the DUP under the bus. Probably the right thing to do.
Blank canvas WPP please if there is time
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Malcolm Barr at JP Morgan, meanwhile, is much less equivocal.

BE11:09am

Brexit: This changes everything - we now expect a deal

BE11:10am

While the more positive mood music emerging from yesterday’s Varadkar-Johnson meeting has some importance of itself, the key question is whether there are substantive proposals behind it which could move the dial toward a deal. At this stage details are scant with both sides remaining tight-lipped ahead of a meeting between Barnier and Barclay in Brussels today. But if our understanding of the situation is correct, a “solution” to the Irish border problem which could ultimately be acceptable to all parties (if rather inelegant) has been identified.

#REF! I love these % probabilities, hilarious
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Here's his reading of what's on the table.

BE11:10am

[T]hink of it as a customs and regulatory border in the Irish Sea, but with rebates to Northern Irish importers so that the tariffs they effectively pay on goods destined for consumption in the province align with those in the UK where they are lower than those in the EU. There are still numerous issues of technical detail, politics, and procedure to be addressed for a Treaty to be ratified which will allow the UK to exit at end October. At least a short technical delay to allow more time for Treaty ratification (including the passage of legislation in the UK) would make a lot of sense for all concerned. But for the first time, a UK exit from the EU on the basis of a Withdrawal Agreement within a matter of weeks now looks the single most likely path ahead, and we have changed the probabilities below
accordingly.

Grouchmonkey If Sinn Feinn's consent is required for an ending of the NI backstop don't see how UP can possibly accept it.
BE11:16am

At this time of writing, the European Commission has no formal mandate from the European Council to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement. And the Council decision granting an Article 50 extension stated explicitly that the agreement would not be reopened. That could leave the legality of any new Treaty presented to EU leaders at the summit next week open to challenge. As should be clear from the above, drafting and agreeing a legal treaty text which gives even the outline of a customs partnership arrangement for Northern Ireland will be a challenge if it is has to be done quickly. Even if there is an impulse from the Republic urging the EU to act swiftly, and a sympathetic response from them, it is very difficult to see a new text being ready to be ratified next week. We could, however, imagine the Council taking a political decision to issue the Commission with a new mandate, and convening a Council Meeting shortly afterward to agree the text of Treaty. The Treaty still then needs to be voted on by the EU Parliament and the legislation to give it effect being passed in the UK so that it can be ratified. Getting all that done by the end of the month will be very difficult.
So what of political support for such a deal in the UK? If the DUP are agreeable to it, and the political declaration has the sorts of changes we expect it to contain, we would expect all but a handful of the Conservative “Spartans” to vote for it. The tweaks to the political declaration will move in the direction of a looser UK-EU relationship than suggested previously. Among those who have left the Conservatives or had the whip removed, only the handful committed to a second referendum would vote against it. The SNP, Labour and Lib Dems would whip against the agreement, and the outturn would ultimately depend on whether there would be enough Labour MPs prepared to abstain or support a deal, despite the whip, for it to pass. Our best guess is that it would. It appears to be PM Johnson’s intention to put a deal along these lines to a vote on Saturday 19th. Note that even if that vote was lost, and Johnson was compelled to by law to send the letter requesting an extension, that does not preclude agreement on a Treaty between the EU and UK being struck and Johnson seeking the support of the Commons for it in short order. Any extension, if granted, can be brought to an end at a date specified in an agreed Withdrawal Treaty. Beyond any technical extension to allow ratifying a deal, we would expect the EU to play along with the idea that it is not minded to grant another Article 50 extension if a second version of a new agreement is reached as a means to put pressure on MPs to vote for it (even if there is an open issue question as to whether that threat would be delivered on in practice).

BE11:17am

Dermot O’Leary of Goodbody gives more time to the DUP hurdle, as you'd expect.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

With Ireland having secured its goal of no hard border on the island of Ireland and the PM securing his goal of being able to strike trade deals with third countries, one can see how both sides can claim victory. The key issue though is whether the DUP can agree to these solutions. The DUP’s line to date has been that it must leave the EU on the same terms as the rest of the UK. It had already moved somewhat on this with the agreement to accept EU rules on goods under the proposals set out by the Boris Johnson government last week. It is reported that the PM had discussions with the DUP prior to yesterday’s meeting, so one would assume that these proposals were first broached with the DUP. If so, their agreement is likely to be enough to get the ERG on board too.

BE11:18am

The second issue discussed at yesterday’s meeting was on the issue of consent and a mechanism by which people in Northern Ireland would get a say on this issue. There is less speculation on this one, but it is likely that some mechanism can be found to do this. Meetings are currently taking place between the EU and the UK on the details of what was discussed yesterday. It seems unlikely that these can be fully fleshed out over the next week in time for the EU Council meeting and then the Saturday sitting of the House of Commons. Even if it is not then, Varadkar and Johnson have opened up the possibility at least of clutching victories from the jaws of defeat. Let’s wait and see.

BE11:24am

But is it sector or company specific? Bit of both, probably. Here's Kepler.

BE11:25am

The declines go beyond attrition (lower spend by FMCG, who has been
focussed on cutting spend with intermediaries like agencies and going
towards a Direct to Consumer model (D2C), where the estimate remained
little changed from earlier in the year (EUR200m, or -2% hit to group
organic, versus EUR150m, or -1.5%, earlier in the year). Reference was
made to weakening in Media, one of the more reliable activities, which
could be cyclical (marketing spend intentions indices are at an 8-year low),
but a major restructure at Sapient in the US is also becoming obvious,
characterised by a conscious or unconscious retreat from some of the
commodity digital activities, which hits organic growth but can be good for
margins, which Publicis claim have improved by 300bp since acquisition.
80% of Epsilon grew at low single-digit, the rest (traditional agency and
affiliate, now being merged into Publicis’ Creative and Media functions)
declined heavily, but overall the outturn was better than Q2’s -4%.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

We slash our Q4 organic growth forecast from +0.8% to -4.7%, which,
together with the miss on Q3, lowers our FY organic decline from -0.3% to
-2.3%. For 2020 we lower our forecast from +2% to -2%, bottom of the
guided range. Confirmation of FY 2019 margin targets (17.3%), which is
partly to do with consolidating Epsilon only for H2 where its margins are
higher, but which was nonetheless above our previous forecast (17%),
limits the EPS downgrade for 2019 to less than -1%. For 2020, though, the
hit is more significant (around -5%), given the margin guidance (17%),
which we maintain for the foreseeable future (i.e. no margin growth out to
2022). Our fair value is based on the mean of the 15-year low EV/EBITA
multiple (8.3x in 2008) and the 15-year average (10.5x), i.e. 9.4x on 2020
forecasts. Applying this lowers marginally our TP from EUR55 to EUR54.
As we would expect the share to fall heavily this morning, that still leaves
significant upside, but investors would need to have a long time horizon.

Just on WPP (BUY, 1450p TP) and the hit it is taking off the Publicis warning last night that WPP published in their Kantar circular on Tuesday that "There has been no significant change to the current trading of the Group since this statement was made. A further update on current trading and prospects of the Group will be provided when results for the nine-month period ended 30 September 2019 are published on 25 October 2019." Suggests there is not going to be a warning from WPP and supports our view the issues at Publicis are more firm specific.

marktime There must be a bunch of shorters getting burned today
11:27 am
BE11:28am

PP’s shares have been impacted by Publicis’ top-line warning for both 2019E and its 2020 guidance of -2% to 1% organic revenue growth. This has raised fears that WPP will also see worsening trends in Q3. However, we think Publicis’ problems are more firm specific than anything else despite the claims from the group that general industry trends were at the room of its problems. Of the four reasons we identified for Publicis’ weakness, only one really applies to WPP (with one a partial read-across)

1. Publicis has bitten off more than it can chew – PUBLICIS SPECIFIC. The history of Publicis in recent years has been major acquisitions (Sapient, Epsilon etc.) that require major integration efforts and can lead management to take its eyes off the ball on the running of the core business.

2. Despite these deals, which were supposed to fuel organic revenue growth – PUBLICIS SPECIFIC. Publicis lags its peers at the top-line. That suggests these assets may not be as high quality as portrayed (indeed Epsilon looks to be declining low single digit organically judging from the comments on the call);

3. Concentration of clients – MORE PUBLICIS SPECIFIC. 34% of Publicis’ revenues comes from its top 30 clients. WPP has 14% from its top 10 clients. There is no like for like comparable here but our suspicion is that Publicis’ top 10 clients is probably more like 20%+ (historically, Publicis was more concentrated). That makes trading more volatile to major clients reducing spending;

4. Its digital offering – APPLIES TO BOTH PUBLICIS AND WPP. This is more controversial but it is noticeable that the two agency groups (WPP and Publicis) which made the most of their digital strengths in the early 2010s have been the most impacted in recent years on their top-line performance. We suspect both these groups have been more impacted by the ANA / client dissatisfaction over digital media buying than perhaps the likes of Omnicom and Interpublic.

BE11:44am

BP has issued an update ahead of 3Q results outlining the progress on its divestment plan, as well as highlighting asset write-downs and additional
maintenance in 3Q. Plan to deliver $10bn announced divestments by end 2019. BP has outlined that it expects to deliver $10bn in divestment proceeds and announced transactions totalling around $10bn by the end of 2019 (we read this as not all being cashed in by end of the year), ahead of its prior target of completing the deals over 2019-20. The most significant asset announced so far was BP’s assets in Alaska, which were sold to Hilcorp for $5.6bn .... While this move is encouraging in some ways, we continue to see it as a difficult market for asset sales in the upstream, and therefore expect valuations to be depressed for asset sales. This is also confirmed by BP’s write-downs today. Taking a non-cash charge of $2-3bn alongside divestments. BP expects to take a charge of $2-3bn at its 3Q results as a result of the agreed divestments. The company has not stated whether this is related to a specific asset or sale. The impairment will have a negative impact on gearing in the short term (equity to shrink), and gearing is expected to remain above the top end of the 20-30% range through the year before moving back to the range through 2020. Given the
significant de-rating in US E&P land, we question whether this relates to BP’s legacy US onshore gas operations, however await further quality at 3Q results. Highlighting additional outages and higher tax rate at 3Q results on 29th October. As a result of turnarounds and disruptions in the US GoM due to Hurricane Barry, which shut in production for 14 days, BP expects production to be down by around 100kboed. This is likely to be weighted towards high-margin and low-tax barrels, and BP now guides to a 50% tax rate in 3Q, vs the normal range of ~40%. The combination of these factors could drive consensus EPS for 3Q down by ~30%.

BE11:44am

Our view – Short-term headwinds highlight a challenging market
Aside from the GoM outages, which are clearly likely to drive downgrades to earnings around 3Q results (lower volumes and higher average tax rate), we think
the write-downs related to divestments are another indicator that it remains challenging to sell upstream assets at healthy valuations in the current environment.

· No news is good news: We've had "positive" headlines due to no slap down of the UK's ideas, meaning that there is something that is workable over the next few days. But we have no actual clue as to what has been put forward either. The EU are refusing to outline the plan at this stage (as they are "in the tunnel").

· Why GBP strength has more to go if we actually do get some credible good news: If we are truly moving to a state where the market is more neutral on GBP (and dare I say it flips to net long), then the typical reaction function of GBP positioning vs price action would take us 6-7% higher from the levels of last Tuesdays report (see here). We have so far only had a move of ~2.25% since last Tuesday, so it’s one of the many reasons why we remain short EUR/GBP

BE11:56am

Two key questions as always when it comes to the deal:

1. Is there a UK/EU deal in sight? Headlines as we know suggest there may be. IF there isn't then the focus shifts back to what the government decides to do and how parliament reacts (Benn Act extension, SO24s, VONCs all likely to come).

2. Can any deal pass parliament? A much harder question, very hard whatever is brought to the house.

a. We need to know what the deal actually is. It’s possible we still will not find out today.

b. Key players will be DUP/ERG/Labour leavers.

If you get all three then there is a good chance it can just get through. But without the Labour Leavers it would be another tight vote and narrow loss for the gov.

Reminder that deal = transition period with years of negotiations on the future trading relationship, with votes on whether to extend this transition period (beyond 2020) and votes on the final future relationship itself. Also if the EU say it's too soon before the summit to get a deal wrapped up. The EU have said in the past they are ready to hold another emergency summit before 31 October (dates yet to be known).

BE12:03pm

Challenging times. Jupiter’s AuM update this morning covers the three months to 30 September, with the group suffering material net outflows from the European Growth strategy in advance of the manager change. At the end of the quarter, assets stood at £45.1bn (a decrease of 2%), with positive investment performance amounting to £0.5bn. Against that, there were net outflows of £1.3bn, driven by a number of specific points: Net outflows of £1.1bn from the European Growth strategy, in advance of the manager change which took place on 1 October. The statement confirms that Alexander Darwall will leave the group in mid-November.
Stripping these out, there were modest inflows into other products. Two new funds were launched in the quarter (Flexible Macro and Global High Yield Short Duration Bond).
Jupiter also suffered the withdrawal by two clients of £0.7bn in segregated mandates, although this was offset by two new mandates for £0.4bn

nightingale20201 @BE...(Re: JUP)...the management couldn't wish a better day to release the result despite they are terrible. Sometime you need a bit of luck...
marktime It is a disruptive but peaceful protest best handled with humour if not restraint by the police but she seems as though she is being driven to make it worse
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Impact on forecasts. We will review our forecasts, with clearly the lower asset levels and outflows likely to negatively impact our estimates. We were looking for PBT/EPS of £164.5m/28.7p, which was slightly ahead of consensus of £158m/28.1p. Although the impact on the current year is likely to be relatively modest, there will be a bigger impact next year.
Valuation and recommendation. On an EV/EBIT basis, Jupiter trades on 7.2x (before any changes) against a sector average of c10x. The dividend yield stands at 7.5%. To some extent this already reflects the expected outflows from the Euro funds, although this masks that Q3 had the strongest level of gross inflows for some time. We had turned positive a few months ago, which has proven too early so far, but Jupiter retains a strong brand and once the period of uncertainty passes, the business should be able to move forward again.
